legacy.description: Per aspera ad astra. @EivorKoy
legacy.name: Eivor Vågslid

result.text:
National Geographic is the latest example of the "uncultured" criticizing China for "cultural genocide."

On October 3, National Geographic released a story on Chinese Weibo that stated, "The Manchu language was once the official language of 300 million people, but now even the Manchu people, with a population of over 10 million, cannot find a single person who can speak the language. How did the official language disappear?"

In a hilarious twist, they took a picture of the Latin text of The Treaty of Nerchinsk, the first treaty between the Tsardom of Russia and the Qing dynasty of China, and thought it was written in Manchu. However, the title "Латинский текст Нерчинского Договора  " (Latin text of the Treaty of Nerchinsk in Russian) was clearly shown on the page, not to mention that the Manchu language uses modified Mongolian writing system, which goes from left to right and up to down.

They also added the misleading headline "Manchu language JUST disappeared," an evident attempt to perpetuate their "China cultural genocide" narrative, except this time it's Manchu rather than Tibetan, Uyghur, or Mongolian.

Countless US politicians and organizations have displayed this type of ludicrous hypocrisy by seeming to care about minorities in China and being unable to recognize their language correctly.

Here are some facts about the Manchu language's decline:

🈵️ There were never many Manchu speakers. Although the Manchu language was the imperial language of China during the Qing Dynasty, it was restricted to the Manchu ethnic people. The number of speakers started to decrease during the middle of the Qing Dynasty, and the last emperor could not speak Manchu fluently.

🈵️ As Manchu officials became more sinicized, many lost their native tongue. The Qing government attempted many strategies to promote Manchu language use, but the results were dismal. As the Yongzheng Emperor (reigned 1722-1735) put it, "If some special encouragement... is not offered, the ancestral language will not be passed on and learned."

🈵️ Historical records report that as early as 1776, the Qianlong Emperor (reigned 1735-1796) was shocked to see a high Manchu official, Guo'ermin, not understand what the emperor told him in Manchu despite coming from the Manchu stronghold of Shengjing. By the 19th century, even the imperial court had lost fluency in the language. The Jiaqing Emperor (reigned 1796–1820) complained that his officials did not understand or write Manchu.

🈵️ Following the fall of the Qing Dynasty, most Manchu people who could still speak the Manchu language abandoned their language in favour of Mandarin, which is more widely spoken and helpful in finding work. 

The Chinese government is concerned about the extinction of the Manchu language because so many Qing dynasty documents were written in Manchu, and we need fluent speakers to keep our history and culture alive.

China has been trying to revitalize the Manchu language by encouraging schools and universities to offer Manchu classes and establish research centres, but interest in the language has been low because of its limited practical application in modern life, and this has led to disappointing results.

This is why a Chinese language resource protection project (中国语言资源保护工程) was launched in 2015 to protect those endangered languages. It has completed research and protection work at over 1,700 sites in its first phase in China, covering more than 120 languages and dialects.

Many books about the languages and dialects of different ethnic minorities and places in China and related cultural phenomena have been published under the project.

Protecting endangered languages necessitates the collaboration of both the government and society, and it can be a difficult and time-consuming endeavour. We need professional linguists like @Goryodynasty to assist us, not some layperson who utilizes these endangered languages to further their political and ideological agenda.

legacy.full_text:
National Geographic is the latest example of the "uncultured" criticizing China for "cultural genocide."

On October 3, National Geographic released a story on Chinese Weibo that stated, "The Manchu language was once the official language of 300 million people, but now even the… https://t.co/tvMHur2LIP

I remembered a part in the book Soulstealers by Harvard historian Philip A. Kuhn --  the Qianlong Emperor was anxious about the Manchu language incompetence shown by some high-level officials as some of them made lots of mistakes, and some even can't understand the language.

legacy.description: Share fun things about Chinese history | Explore stories of artifacts | Try to update on a daily basis
legacy.name: History is fun

legacy.full_text:
In Cave 285 of Mogao Grottoes, a Zen monk is seen on a chair with high backrest and four legs. The cave was built as early as 538 CE. 

It is beleived to be the earliest image of such kind of chair among all the #frescos in Dunhuang, NW #China.
 #Historyisfun 🪑 https://t.co/HJ2goDJwhu

value.string_value: Ex-Japanese PM Shinzo Abe dies after being shot

Former Japanese PM Shinzo Abe has died after being shot while delivering a speech in the western city of Nara on Friday, public broadcaster NHK reported. 

CGTN Live updates: https://bit.ly/3ADS7Jw
